questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding the anatomy of the spleen?

choices.text: The spleen develops from the ventral mesogastrium
The axis of the spleen lies along the 9th rib
The spleen is partly covered by the peritoneum

questions.solution:
The superior border of the spleen is notched.

The superior border of the spleen separates the diaphragmatic surface from the gastric impression of the visceral surface. It often contains one or two notches. Additionally, there can be a notch on the inferolateral border, and this may be palpated only when the spleen is enlarged. 

Option A: The spleen arises from the primitive mesoderm as an outgrowth of the left side of the dorsal mesogastrium. 

Option B: The spleen is related to the 9th, 10th, and 11th ribs, with its long axis along the 10th rib.

Option D: The spleen is completely intraperitoneal.

questions.text: The downward displacement of the spleen is prevented by which of the following ligaments?
questions.solution:
The phrenocolic ligament prevents the downward displacement of the spleen.

The phrenicocolic ligament is not attached to the spleen. It attaches the splenic flexure of the colon to the diaphragm. When the spleen gets enlarged, the phrenicocolic ligament along with the splenic flexure of the colon restricts its downward displacement.The enlargement of the spleen occurs towards the right iliac fossa and is directed obliquely.

Splenic ligaments and their attachments:

Splenic ligament Attachments  Contents
Phrenicocolic ligament Diaphragm to the splenic flexure of the colon -
Phrenicosplenic ligament Posterior abdominal wall to the upper pole of the spleen -
Splenorenal (lienorenal) ligament Hilum of the spleen to the anterior surface of the left kidney Tail of pancreas
Splenic artery and vein
Gastrosplenic ligament Greater curvature of the stomach to the upper pole of the spleen Short gastric vessels
Left gastroepiploic artery

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for an accessory spleen?
questions.solution:
The most common site for accessory spleen or splenunculi is the splenic hilum. It is the most common anomaly of splenic embryology.

Other locations for accessory spleen in descending order of frequency are:

  • Gastrocolic ligament
  • Pancreatic tail
  • Greater omentum
  • Greater curvature of the stomach 
  • Splenocolic ligament
  • Small and large bowel mesentery
  • Left broad ligament in women
  • Left spermatic cord in men

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presents with complaints of epigastric and lower back pain. Past history is significant for post-traumatic splenectomy at the age of 12 years. CT scan showed multiple nodules scattered across the intestinal loops and under the diaphragm. The tumours were excised following laparotomy and histology was typical for splenic tissue. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of splenosis.

Splenosis refers to the rupture of the spleen and distribution of splenic tissue on the peritoneum. This should be considered as a differential diagnosis when a patient with a splenic injury in the past presents with tumour-like lesions on abdominal imaging.

questions.text: Two weeks following an upper respiratory tract infection, a 5-year-old child presents with a skin rash as shown in the image. She also complains of bleeding gums and her platelet count is 18,000/µL.  Which among the following is false about her condition?

choices.text: Chronic form of this condition is more common in females
Bone marrow examination shows increased megathrombocytes
Splenectomy is the best alternative treatment for this condition

questions.solution:
The image showing petechiae and the given history of a child presenting with mucocutaneous bleed following an upper respiratory tract infection are highly suggestive of immune thrombocytopenic purpura.

In idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), the spleen is palpable in fewer than 10% of the patients, and the presence of gross splenic enlargement should raise the suspicion of an alternative diagnosis.

Management of ITP:

  • In patients with platelet counts <30,000/μL, treatment may be instituted if there are symptoms of life-threatening bleeding.
  • Prednisone at 1 mg/kg is the initial treatment of choice.
  • Rh(D) immune globulin is used only in Rh-positive patients.
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG).
  • Splenectomy is indicated in patients who have relapsed on glucocorticoid therapy. Relapse patients with intermittent or high platelet count can be managed with anti-Rh0(D) immunoglobulin, IVIG, or with a thrombopoietin receptor agonist.
  • Subcutaneous romiplostim and oral eltrombopag are thrombopoietin receptor agonists used in adults who are at risk of bleeding even after splenectomy.

Option A: The acute form is more commonly seen in children following a viral infection, while the chronic form is more often seen in adult women of childbearing years.

Option C: The bone marrow examination can be normal or show an increased number of megathrombocytes.

Option D: 80% of cases undergo spontaneous remission in children. Patients who do not respond to first-line therapy like steroids and IVIG are best treated by splenectomy.

Related Pearl: Idiopathic/Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

It is characterized by

  • Isolated thrombocytopenia—the presence of antibody against platelet membrane glycoprotein and subsequent destruction in reticuloendothelial system
  • Normal bone marrow—normal or even increased number of megakaryocytes
  • Absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia. 

Types:

Acute (<6 months) and chronic (>6 months) idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

questions.text: A young man with idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura is posted for splenectomy. His platelet count is 32000 per cubic millimeter. What is the best time to transfuse platelets in this patient?

choices.text: Immediately after the ligation of splenic artery
Immediately after the ligation of splenic vein

questions.solution:
The best time to transfuse platelets in this patient is immediately after ligation of the splenic artery.

The platelets are destroyed by the spleen within one hour of transfusion, and the splenic artery is the major vessel that brings blood to the spleen. Therefore, the best time to transfuse the platelets is immediately after the ligation of the splenic artery.

questions.text: In a patient with hypersplenism, which of the following features can not be seen?
questions.solution:
Bone marrow failure is not seen in a patient with hypersplenism.

Hypersplenism is an indefinite clinical syndrome that is characterised by:

  • Splenic enlargement
  • Combination of anemia, leucopenia or thrombocytopenia
  • Compensatory bone marrow hyperplasia
  • Improvement after splenectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: Schistosomiasis can lead to tropical splenomegaly
Autosplenectomy is seen in sickle cell anemia
Howell-Jolly bodies are seen in asplenia

questions.solution:
Thrombocytosis occurs following splenectomy.

This occurs particularly in patients with myeloproliferative disorders (e.g., chronic myeloid leukemia, polycythemia vera, essential thrombocytosis). It may result in thrombosis of the mesenteric, portal, and renal veins which can be life-threatening as it can lead to haemorrhage and thromboembolism.

Option A: Tropical splenomegaly is massive splenic enlargement, which frequently occurs in the tropics due to malaria, kala-azar, and schistosomiasis.

Option C: Autosplenectomy is seen in sickle cell anemia. Splenomegaly is seen in thalassemia and hereditary spherocytosis.

Option D: Howell-Jolly bodies are the nuclear remnants present in the RBCs. They appear as dense blue colored circular inclusions as shown in the image below. They are usually seen in patients lacking normal spleen function (asplenia).

questions.text: A young male patient who is on treatment for osteomyelitis was found to have multiple splenic abscesses. This patient is least likely to have which of the following?
questions.solution:
Splenomegaly is not a typical feature of splenic abscess.

Splenic abscesses manifest with vague abdominal pain, fever, peritonitis, and pleuritic chest pain.

A splenic abscess may arise from an infected splenic embolus, or in association with:

  • Typhoid or paratyphoid fever
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Otitis media 
  • Puerperal sepsis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common indication for splenectomy?
questions.solution:
Overall, the most common indication for splenectomy is trauma to the spleen, whether external (blunt or penetrating) or iatrogenic (e.g., during operative procedures for other reasons).

The most common indication for:

  • Elective splenectomy - Haematological disorders such as ITP, TTP, etc.
  • Emergency splenectomy - Trauma
  • Splenectomy (overall) - Trauma.

Related Pearl: Indications for splenectomy

Trauma (most common)

  • Accidental
  • Operative

Oncological

  • Part of en bloc resection
  • Diagnostic
  • Therapeutic

Haematological

  • Spherocytosis
  • Purpura (idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura)
  • Hypersplenism

Portal hypertension

  • Variceal surgery

questions.text: What is the most common complication that is expected to occur in patients following splenectomy?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of greater curvature of stomach

questions.solution:
Left lower lobe atelectasis is the most common complication after splenectomy.

Other complications of splenectomy include:

  • OPSI (Overwhelming post-splenectomy infection)is the most common fatal late complication of splenectomy.
  • Avascular necrosis of the greater curvature of the stomach is a rare complication that can occur after ligation of short gastric vessels.
  • Damage to the tail of the pancreas during surgery can lead to pancreatitis, a localized abscess, or pancreatic fistula.
  • Hemorrhage during the perioperative period etc.

questions.text: Vaccine for post-splenectomy infection is given against all except ______.
questions.solution:
Escherichia coli vaccination is not recommended in post-splenectomy patients.

Currently, the standard of care for post-splenectomy patients includes immunization with the following if the patient did not receive these before surgery:

  • Polyvalent pneumococcal vaccine (PPV23)
  • Haemophilus influenzae type B conjugate vaccine
  • Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine.

Related Pearl: Post-Splenectomy Care

Vaccination:

  • Patients should be vaccinated at least 2 weeks prior, and ideally 10 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy. 
  • When vaccines cannot be given prior to emergency splenectomy, vaccines should be given at least two weeks after splenectomy.

Following vaccines are given:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine: 
    • A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised. 
    • Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.
  • H. influenzae type b vaccine:
    • A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended. 
    • Revaccination is needed every ten years.
  • Meningococcal vaccination:
    • Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart.
    • Revaccination is needed every five years.
  • Influenza vaccination:
    • Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Antibiotics: 

Daily prophylaxis: 

  • Penicillin and amoxicillin are preferred agents
    • For at least 1 year after surgery (at least up to the age of 5 yrs in children)
    • For immunocompromised, at least up to the age of 18 yrs

Early empirical:

  • Early empirical treatment to be initiated in presence of systemic symptoms of infection e.g - chills, rigor, fever, vomiting, etc.
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is the preferred choice for most adults and children
  • If allergic to beta-lactam, use levofloxacin/moxifloxacin.

Antithrombotics:

  • Low dose heparin for at least 4 weeks helps in perioperative thromboembolism prevention
  • In presence of extreme reactive thrombocytosis (>10,00,000/mm3) low dose aspirin can also be given.

questions.text:
Which of the statements regarding opportunistic post-splenectomy infection are correct?
1. Hemophilus influenzae, Neisseria meningitides and, Streptococcus pneumoniae are the most common causative agents
2. Risk is greatest in patients who have undergone splenectomy for trauma
3. Risk is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy
4. Prophylactic vaccination should be done 2 weeks prior to elective splenectomy
5. No vaccination is needed in case of an emergency splenectomy
questions.solution:
The risk of developing opportunistic post-splenectomy infection is greatest when splenectomy is done for haematological conditions than for post-trauma. 

Opportunistic post-splenectomy infection is a major complication following splenectomy due to septicemia, which may result from an infection of:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Neisseria meningitides
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Escherichia coli.

The risk of overwhelming sepsis is greatest within the first 2–3 years following splenectomy.

Hence, if an elective splenectomy is planned, consideration should be given to vaccinating against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) (repeated every 10 years) at least 2 weeks before elective surgery.

In case of emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: A 24-year-old professional football player was tackled hard during a match. He complains of severe pain in the left upper abdomen. On examination, his BP is 100/74 mm Hg and there is tenderness and crepitus over the left 10th and 11th ribs. He also complains of pain over the left shoulder when pressure is applied over the left upper abdominal quadrant. This sign is called:
questions.solution:
Kehr sign refers to referred pain in the tip of the left shoulder when firm pressure is applied over the left upper quadrant. It is also elicited by raising the left leg.

It is seen in the case of hemoperitoneum, especially due to splenic injury. It occurs due to the collection of blood below the diaphragm and irritation of the phrenic nerve. 

Option A: Ballance sign is also seen in splenic injury. It is an area of percussive dullness in the left upper quadrant due to the coagulation of blood from the injured spleen.

Option B: Cullen sign refers to periumbilical bruising in cases of hemoperitoneum, especially those of pancreatic origin. 

Option D: Grey Turner sign refers to bluish discolouration around flanks in case of hemoperitoneum especially acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding splenic artery aneurysms is true?

choices.text: It is the most common visceral artery aneurysm
The most common presentation is severe epigastric pain
Rupture is more common during the second trimester of pregnancy
All diagnosed cases require surgical intervention

questions.solution:
Splenic artery aneurysm is the commonest visceral artery aneurysm.

Splenic artery aneurysm occurs more commonly in females. It is usually situated in the main arterial trunk. It is usually asymptomatic unless it ruptures. During pregnancy, rupture is more common in the third trimester and in labour.

CT angiography is the investigation of choice. Not all diagnosed cases of splenic artery aneurysms need intervention. 

Treatment should be considered in aneurysms larger than 2 cm in diameter.

In an elderly patient with a calcified aneurysm, there is less risk of rupture and observation may be preferred. In a younger patient with an asymptomatic aneurysm, surgery or interventional radiology is indicated. 

In patients with pancreatic necrosis, the treatment should include drainage of the septic focus.

The treatment comprises of:

  • Ligation of the proximal and distal ends of the sac
  • Embolization or endovascular stenting
  • Splenectomy with the removal of the artery

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cyst of the spleen?
questions.solution:
The most common splenic cyst is pseudocyst, secondary to trauma. These are termed pseudocysts due to their lack of cellular lining.

Splenic cysts are classified as either parasitic or non-parasitic:

  • Parasitic/hydatid cysts are the most common true/primary splenic cysts
  • Splenic pseudocysts are the most common non-parasitic splenic cysts and occur following trauma
  • Epidermoid cysts are the most common non-traumatic, non-parasitic splenic cysts.

Note: These epithelial cells are often positive for CA 19-9 and carcinoembryonic antigen by immunohistochemistry. Patients with splenic epidermoid cysts may have elevated serum levels of one or both of these tumor markers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding tumors of the spleen is true?

choices.text: The most common primary malignant tumor of the spleen is hemangiosarcoma
The most common primary benign tumor of the spleen is hemangioma
The most common cause of isolated splenic metastasis is gastric carcinoma
The most common cause of neoplastic splenic enlargement is metastasis

questions.solution:
The most common primary tumor of the spleen is hemangioma.

Option A: Lymphoma (not Hemangiosarcoma) is the most common malignant primary tumour of the spleen.

Option C: Ovarian carcinoma is the most common cause of isolated splenic metastasis

Option D: Lymphoma is the most common cause of neoplastic splenic enlargement and the most common malignant tumour associated with splenic involvement.
